Explanation:

 

The ML Cu 375 intrauterine device is known for its very low pregnancy rates, which are typically less than 1 per 100 women years. This exceptionally low rate is due to the device's efficient design and larger copper surface area, which enhances its contraceptive efficacy. The categorization of IUDs based on pregnancy rates places ML Cu 375 in the highest efficacy group.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lippe’s loop: Incorrect, as it belongs to an older generation of IUDs with generally higher pregnancy rates compared to more modern copper IUDs like the ML Cu 375.

 

Option B. CuT-200: Incorrect, this device also has a higher pregnancy rate than ML Cu 375, making it less effective in comparison.

 

Option C. Nova-T: Incorrect, although it is an effective IUD, its pregnancy rates are still higher than those associated with ML Cu 375, placing it in a different efficacy category.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ML Cu 375 is the most effective intrauterine device listed in terms of preventing pregnancy, with rates less than 1 per 100 women years.

questions.text: Which of the following is a PCSK9 inhibitor? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Evolocumab
 

Alirocumab and Evolocumab are PCSK9 (proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type 9) inhibitors. These works by inhibiting the PCSK9 enzyme which is responsible for degradation of LDL receptors in the liver. Therefore, these drugs lead to an increased number of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) receptors on liver cells and a subsequent decrease in LDL cholesterol levels in the blood. PCSK9 inhibitors are used for lowering cholesterol levels, particularly in patients with familial hypercholesterolemia or those who are at high risk for cardiovascular disease and have not adequately responded to statins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ezetimibe: Ezetimibe works by inhibiting the absorption of cholesterol in the small intestine, which leads to a reduction in the total amount of cholesterol presented to the liver. It does not inhibit PCSK9.

 

Option C. Bempedoic Acid: Bempedoic acid is a relatively new cholesterol-lowering medication. It inhibits ATP citrate lyase, an enzyme involved in cholesterol synthesis, but it is not a PCSK9 inhibitor.

 

Option D. Clofibrate: Clofibrate is a fibrate used to lower lipid levels, particularly triglycerides. It works by activating peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors (PPARs) and does not inhibit PCSK9.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Evolocumab is a PCSK9 inhibitor that works by blocking the PCSK9 enzyme, leading to increased LDL receptor availability on liver cells and reduced LDL cholesterol levels in the blood.

questions.text: A patient comes to the emergency room with a history of multiple episodes of vomiting. After being administered an intravenous drug for treatment, he develops abnormal movements. Which of the following medications can be used to manage his abnormal movements? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Benzhexol

 

Benzhexol (also known as trihexyphenidyl) is an anticholinergic agent often used to treat extrapyramidal symptoms, which include abnormal involuntary movements. These symptoms can occur as a side effect of D2 blockers like antipsychotics and some antiemetics like metoclopramide that may have been used to treat the vomiting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyoscine: This is an antispasmodic and anticholinergic drug mainly used for motion sickness and gastrointestinal spasms. It is not specifically used for treating abnormal movements such as extrapyramidal symptoms.

 

Option B. Cyproheptadine: This is an antihistamine and anticholinergic medication used mainly for allergic reactions. It is not primarily indicated for the treatment of abnormal movements.

 

Option C. Levodopa: This medication is primarily used for treating Parkinson's disease and is not indicated for the treatment of drug-induced abnormal movements unless those symptoms are related to Parkinson’s disease.

 

Therefore, in this patient who developed abnormal movements possibly due to a drug side effect, Benzhexol would be the appropriate medication for managing his symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Benzhexol (trihexyphenidyl) is the drug of choice for managing extrapyramidal symptoms, which include abnormal movements induced by medications such as D2 receptor blockers.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a prodrug? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Primidone

 

  • Prodrugs are drugs that are present in their inactive form and are converted to the active form in the body after undergoing metabolism.
  • Among the given options primidone is not a prodrug. Although it produces active metabolites like phenobarbitone and phenylethylmalonamide (PEMA) but it cannot be considered as a prodrug because primidone itself is also active.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Proguanil: Proguanil is a prodrug and its active metabolite is cycloguanil. It is used in the treatment and prevention of malaria.

 

Option C. Sulindac: Sulindac is a sulfoxide prodrug used in inflammatory diseases including osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, ankylosing spondylitis.

 

Option D. Flurouracil: Flurouracil  is a prodrug having the active metabolite as fluorouridine monophosphate. It is an anticancer chemotherapeutic agent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primidone is not a prodrug because it is pharmacologically active in its original form, although it also produces active metabolites. Prodrugs like Proguanil, Sulindac, and 5-Fluorouracil require metabolic activation to exert their therapeutic effects.

 

Mnemonic

questions.text: Which of the following phases of a clinical trial is also referred to as efficacy trial? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Phase 3

 

Phase 3 of a clinical trial is often referred to as an efficacy trial. This is because phase 3 trials are designed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of the investigational drug or intervention in a larger and more diverse patient population. Phase 3 trials typically involve several hundred to several thousand participants and are usually randomized, controlled trials that compare the investigational drug or intervention to either a placebo or an active comparator.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phase 1 trials are typically the first-in-human studies and are designed to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics of the investigational drug or intervention.

 

Option B. Phase 2 trials are designed to evaluate the safety and preliminary efficacy of the investigational drug or intervention in a larger patient population than in phase 1 trials.

 

Option D. Phase 4 trials, also known as post-marketing surveillance studies, are conducted after a drug or intervention has been approved by regulatory agencies and are designed to monitor the long-term safety and effectiveness of the drug or intervention in a larger patient population than in earlier phases of the trial.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following newly approved drugs is used in the treatment of IgA nephropathy? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sparsentan

 

Explanation:


Sparsentan is a novel dual-acting antagonist of the endothelin receptor type A and angiotensin II receptor type 1 (AT1). It is specifically approved for the treatment of IgA nephropathy, a kidney disorder characterized by the deposition of IgA antibodies in the glomeruli, leading to proteinuria and progressive kidney damage. Sparsentan reduces proteinuria and delays progression of kidney disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Trofinetide – Trofinetide is approved for Rett syndrome and exhibits neuroprotective properties but has no role in IgA nephropathy.

 

Option B: Zavegepant – Zavegepant is a calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) antagonist approved for the treatment of migraine.

 

Option D: Elacestrant – Elacestrant is a selective estrogen receptor degrader (SERD) approved for hormone receptor-positive breast cancer.

 

Educational Objective:


Sparsentan is a new dual-action drug specifically approved for IgA nephropathy, highlighting advancements in targeted therapy for kidney diseases. Understanding its mechanism and clinical use is crucial for managing proteinuric kidney disorders.

questions.text: After parotid surgery, the patient is found to have weakness of the lower lip on the ipsilateral side. Which of these injuries is likely to produce this? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cervical branch of facial nerve

 

In this scenario, the patient has undergone parotid surgery and subsequently developed weakness of the lower lip on the same side as the surgery (ipsilateral). This kind of symptom indicates a nerve injury.

 

  • Facial Nerve Branches: The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) is responsible for motor control of the muscles of facial expression. It divides into several branches after it exits the stylomastoid foramen, including the temporal, zygomatic, buccal, mandibular (marginal mandibular), and cervical branches.
  • Cervical Branch: The cervical branch of the facial nerve, along with the marginal mandibular branch, supplies the muscles of the lower face, including those involved in the movement of the lower lip. An injury to the cervical branch could result in weakness of the lower lip, which is consistent with the patient's presentation.
  • Marginal Mandibular Branch: Although the marginal mandibular branch is primarily responsible for the lower lip, in cases where this specific branch is not listed as an option, the cervical branch is the closest and most accurate choice because it is part of the lower division of the facial nerve that supplies the lower lip muscles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Main trunk of the facial nerve: Injury to the main trunk of the facial nerve would likely cause more extensive symptoms, including the inability to close the eye (Bell's phenomenon), loss of forehead wrinkling, and other signs of lower motor neuron facial paralysis, which are not mentioned in this case. Therefore, this option is less likely.

 

Option B. Temporal branch of the facial nerve: The temporal branch of the facial nerve innervates muscles in the upper face, such as those involved in raising the eyebrows and closing the eyelids. It does not affect the lower lip, making this option incorrect.

 

Option D. Parotid duct: Injury to the parotid duct would result in issues related to salivation, such as a salivary fistula, but it would not cause motor weakness of the lower lip. This option is also incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Weakness of the lower lip after parotid surgery is most likely due to injury to the cervical branch of the facial nerve. The marginal mandibular branch is the most specific, but if not listed, the cervical branch is the closest correct option

questions.text: Which among the following serves as cofactor for Glycogen phosphorylase? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pyridoxal Phosphate

 

Glycogen phosphorylase removes glucose as glucose- 1-phosphate from glycogen (phosphorolysis). It contains pyridoxal phosphate (PLP) as a prosthetic group. The alpha-1, 4 linkages in the glycogen are cleaved.

 

PLP also acts as the coenzyme for many enzymes involved in

 

  • Amino acid metabolism, especially transamination and decarboxylation
  • Heme synthesis
  • Production of niacin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiamine: Thiamine is a cofactor for enzymes involved in carbohydrate metabolism, such as pyruvate dehydrogenase and alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, but it is not a cofactor for glycogen phosphorylase.

 

Option B. Niacin: Niacin is a precursor for NAD and NADP, which are important cofactors in redox reactions, but it does not serve as a cofactor for glycogen phosphorylase.

 

Option D. Biotin: Biotin is a cofactor for carboxylation reactions, such as those catalyzed by pyruvate carboxylase, acetyl-CoA carboxylase, and propionyl-CoA carboxylase, but it is not involved with glycogen phosphorylase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyridoxal phosphate (PLP) is the cofactor for glycogen phosphorylase and is also involved in amino acid metabolism, heme synthesis, and niacin production.

choices.text: Drug A decreases intestinal absorption of Drug B
﻿﻿﻿Drug A reduces first pass metabolism of Drug B
﻿﻿﻿Drug A increases the metabolism of Drug B
Drug A increases renal elimination of Drug B

questions.text: The table below gives the AUC of drug B alone and that of drug B when combined with another drug A. If the p value is <0.01, then which of the following statements is true? (INICET 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Drug A reduces first pass metabolism of Drug B
 

  • The area under the curve or AUC in plasma concentration vs time graph can be used as a measure of the bioavailability of a drug. The bioavailability of a given drug refers to the fraction of the given dose which reaches the systemic circulation. The greater the area under the curve or AUC, the greater is the bioavailability.
  • From the given data, it is seen that the AUC for Drug B is less than the AUC for Drug A + Drug B. And the p value <0.01 indicates that the data is statistically significant. (As the p value is <0.05)
  • So, it can be inferred that the Drug A increases the bioavailability of drug B.

 

As bioavailability depends on two factors:

 

  • Absorption (Bioavailability is directly proportional to the rate of drug absorption)
  • First Pass Metabolism (Bioavailability is inversely proportional to the rate of first pass metabolism of the drug)
  • Therefore, it can be assumed that drug B either increase the absorption or decrease the first pass metabolism of drug A.
  • So among the given options, best answer seem to be option B: Drug A reduces the first pass metabolism of drug B

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Drug A decreases intestinal absorption of Drug B: This statement is incorrect. If Drug A decreased the intestinal absorption of Drug B, the AUC would be lower when the drugs are combined, not higher.

 

Option C. Drug A increases the metabolism of Drug B: This statement is incorrect. If Drug A increased the metabolism of Drug B, the AUC would be lower when the drugs are combined.

 

Option D. Drug A increases renal elimination of Drug B: This statement is incorrect. If Drug A increased the renal elimination of Drug B, it would lead to a decrease in AUC, not an increase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The increase in the AUC of Drug B when combined with Drug A, with a statistically significant p value, indicates that Drug A reduces the first pass metabolism of Drug B, thereby increasing its bioavailability.

questions.text: What is the site of action of amphotericin B in fungi? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cell membrane

 

Amphotericin B is an antifungal drug that acts by sequestering ergosterol in the cell membrane, it leads to formation of pores in the cell membrane that leads to leakage of cytosolic contents out of the cell and eventually death of the fungus.. It is the drug of choice in systemic fungal infections , mucormycosis , cryptococcal meningitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nucleic acid: Amphotericin B does not target nucleic acids. Antifungal drugs that affect nucleic acid synthesis include flucytosine.

 

Option B. Ribosome: Amphotericin B does not target ribosomes. Antifungal drugs that interfere with protein synthesis at the ribosomal level are not commonly used.

 

Option D. Cytoplasm: Amphotericin B acts at the cell membrane, not directly within the cytoplasm. The disruption of the cell membrane causes the loss of cytoplasmic contents.

 

Additional Information

 

  • Mechanism of Action: By binding to ergosterol and forming pores, amphotericin B disrupts the integrity of the fungal cell membrane, leading to cell death.
  • Uses: Amphotericin B is the drug of choice for treating systemic fungal infections, mucormycosis, and cryptococcal meningitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amphotericin B targets the cell membrane of fungi by binding to ergosterol, forming pores that lead to leakage of cytoplasmic contents and fungal cell death. It is highly effective in treating severe systemic fungal infections.
